title: Defining the interactomes of proteins involved in cytoskeletal dynamics using high-throughput proximity-dependent biotinylation in cellulo
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell plating and treatments
Timing: 2 days
These steps are required to induce the expression of the POI fused to BirA∗ in the stable Flp-In T-REx cell line. To robustly biotinylate proximity proteins, BirA∗ requires exogenous biotin as a substrate.
Seed the Flp-In T-REx stable cell line in a 15 cm dish cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% TET-free FBS and allow them to adhere and proliferate overnight (about 16 h). The number of cells can vary from one cell line to another and should be optimized in each lab.
When the confluency reaches 75%–80% treat the cells.
Aspirate the media.
Gently replace it with fresh media supplemented with 10% of FBS, 1 ug/mL of tetracycline and 50 μM of biotin for 24 h.
Note: The treatments can otherwise be added directly to the cells.
Cell harvesting
Timing: 40 min
These steps describe how to properly harvest the cells prior to performing the BioID.
Note: The following steps are done on ice.
Aspirate the media and add 5 mL of ice-cold PBS to the dish.
Agitate on an orbital shaker at 4°C for 10 min.
Scrape the cells using a cell scraper and transfer them to a 15 cm tube.
Add 7 mL of cold PBS to the dish.
Collect the remaining cells and transfer into the same 15 cm tube.
Pellet the cells by centrifuging at 500 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Wash the pellet with 10 mL of cold PBS.
Repeat steps 8–10.
Pellet the cells by centrifuging at 500 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Pause point: At this point, you can freeze the cell pellets at −80°C for several months. This can be useful to synchronize the processing of samples from different experiments.

Affinity capture of biotinylated proteins
Timing: 5–7 h depending on the number of samples
These steps explain how to lyse the cells and how to capture the proteins that were biotinylated by BirA∗ in cellulo using streptavidin Sepharose® beads.
Note: Keep the samples on ice.
Thaw frozen cell pellets in 1,5 mL of ice-cold RIPA lysis buffer supplemented with inhibitors (DTT, PMSF and protease cocktail inhibitor).
Resuspend by pipetting up and down
Transfer to a 2 mL Eppendorf tube.
Add 1 μL of benzonase (250 U/μL) to each sample to digest nucleic acids, prior to the following step.
To complete cell lysis, sonicate samples for 30 s at 30% amplitude. Perform 3 rounds of 10 s with 2 s pause in between.
Note: Ideally, the sonication performed at step 16 should be done on ice. If not possible, the sample can be taken from the ice and replaced back after.
Centrifuge the lysates for 30 min at 12,000 g at 4°C to pellet the cell debris.
Meanwhile wash 70 μL of streptavidin Sepharose® beads slurry in a 2 mL Eppendorf tube.
Add 1 mL of RIPA buffer (with or without inhibitors) to the 70 μL of beads.
Spin for 1 min at 375 g at 4°C to pellet the beads.
Aspirate the wash buffer.
Repeat step 18 two more times.
Collect the clarified cell lysates of step 17 and transfer it to the 2 mL Eppendorf tube containing 70 μL of the pre-washed beads.
Note: A 20 μl or 40 μL aliquot of the supernatant should ideally be stored at −80°C to monitor protein expression, lysis efficiency and solubility.
Secure tubes with parafilm to prevent leaking.
Incubate with rotation at 4°C for 3 h.
Spin down the beads by centrifuging them for 1 min at 375 g at 4°C.

Remove the supernatant.
Note: You can keep the supernatant to monitor unbound bait as a control and store it at −80°C.
Add 1 mL of RIPA lysis buffer without inhibitors to the beads and transfer to a new 2 mL Eppendorf tube to remove unwanted material that adhered to the tube walls.
Spin down the beads by centrifuging them for 1 min at 375 g at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash with 1 mL of RIPA lysis buffer.
Repeat steps 25–26 one more time.
Centrifuge 1 min at 375 g at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the beads with 1 mL of 50 mM cold ABC which provides an optimal pH for the trypsin digestion and is also compatible with the downstream MS analysis.
Repeat step 28–29 two times and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend beads in 100 μL of 50 mM cold ABC.
Biotinylated proteins digestion
Timing: 18 h
These steps allow the trypsin-mediated digestion of the bound biotinylated proteins. It is essential to work in a clean environment for steps 32–46.
Resuspend trypsin stock in 200 μL of 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 8,0 by vortexing for around one minute and make sure it is well dissolved.
Critical: Wear a mask to perform this step, trypsin powder can be harmful to the respiratory tract.
Add 10 μL (1 μg) of resuspended trypsin to each sample.
Secure tube with parafilm to prevent leaking.
Incubate overnight (about 15 h) at 37°C with rotation to digest peptides. Make sure all samples rotate correctly.
The next day, resuspend a new tube of trypsin stock in 200 μL of 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 8,0.
Note: It is important to use a new tube of trypsin each day. Trypsin stored at 4°C overnight can lose its activity.

Add 10 μL (1 μg) of resuspended trypsin to each sample.
Secure tube with parafilm to prevent leaking.
Incubate for 2 h at 37°C with rotation to make sure proteins are maximally digested.
Peptide recovery
Timing: 4–5 h depending on the number of samples
These steps describe how to collect the released peptides from the digestion and how to concentrate them.
Pellet the beads by centrifugation for 1 min at 375 g at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Transfer 100 μL of supernatant which contains peptides to a 1,5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Note: From now on be careful not to carry over any beads. To avoid disturbing the bead pellet, we recommend limiting movement by staying close to the centrifuge and manipulating the samples the least possible.
Rinse beads with 100 μL of HPLC grade water.
Centrifuge the beads for 1 min at 375 g at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Collect the supernatant containing the remaining peptides in the same tube as step 41 to pool all peptides.
Repeat steps 42–44 one more time.
Add 30 μL of 50% formic acid stock solution for a final concentration of 5% formic acid to the 1,5 mL Eppendorf tube containing peptide to end digestion and mix by pipetting up and down.
Centrifuge for 10 min at 16300 g at room temperature (20°C–25°C) to pellet remaining beads.
Transfer supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube making sure not to carry over any beads by leaving a few μL (5–15) in the tube.
Repeat steps 47 and 48 again.
Place samples in a SpeedVac for 3 h at maximum speed and 35°C to dry completely.
Freeze samples at −80°C.
Pause point: Frozen samples can be stored for several months.

Before MS injection, resuspend the pellet in 15 μL of 5% formic acid by pipetting up and down.
MS injection
Timing: 145 min/sample
These steps of the protocol describe how to inject the samples prepared above in the LC-MS/MS system.
For each series of samples (duplicates or triplicates) perform an LC-MS/MS analysis using a short concentration gradient on at least one diluted sample (1:20) prior to the full gradient injection.
Critical: This run is important as it allows to determine the highest volume to be injected for the full gradient analysis. The goal is to reach the maximum sensitivity without saturating the LC-MS/MS system.
Load the samples at the previously determined dilution into a 75 μm i.d. × 150 mm Self-Pack C18 column installed on the Easy-nLC II or the Easy-nLC 1000 system.
Elute the peptides with a two-slope gradient at a flow rate of 250 nL/min (The HPLC system is either coupled to a Q Exactive or the LTQ Orbitrap Velos mass spectrometer through a Nanospray Flex Ion Source.)
Set the Nanospray and S-lens voltages to 1.3–1.7 kV and 50–60 V, respectively.
Set the capillary temperature to 250°C.
Increase solvent B from 2 to 36% in 100 min and then from 36 to 82% B in 10 min.
Acquire full scan MS survey spectra (m/z 360–2000) in profile mode in the Orbitrap with a resolution of 60,000 and the AGC target at 1E6.
Depending on the machine available follow the steps (a) or (b) below:
On the Q Exactive
Fragment the 16 most intense peptide ions in the collision cell at a normalized collision energy of 27.
Analyze MS/MS spectra in the Orbitrap with a resolution of 17,500, the AGC target at 1E5, and the dynamical exclusion set to 7 s.
On the LTQ Orbitrap Velos

Fragment the 11 most intense peptide ions in the high-pressure cell at a normalized collision energy of 35.
Analyze MS/MS spectra in the linear trap with the AGC target at 1E4 and the dynamical exclusion set to 30 s.
